text: “We do not beg the gods. We earn their gaze.”
His word is law. His silence is war.
“My tribe follows me not out of love. But because they fear what I fear less.”
“Skulls speak. If you know how to listen.”
He taught them to stalk. You taught them to fall.
The border burns — but this time, it holds.
Dipped in the blood of a hundred captains and flown in a storm of crimson snow.
He leads not by glory, but by survival — by the bite of axe and oath.
Jarl of the Snaegr, heir to a daemon’s hunger — he is born in ice, crowned in blood.

Grydal is not the first jarl of the Snaegr, but he may well be the last who draws breath. A warlord born of endless raids, blood-feuds, and ice-bound desperation, he forged his reputation not with boasts but with results: burned villages, broken tribes, and a shieldwall that does not yield. The Snaegr once scrounged the edges of Norsca, feared more for their madness than their strength. But under Grydal, they became something more — unrelenting. Some whisper that he speaks to ancestors, that the moon of Urlf burns brighter when he chants. Grydal does not deny it. He simply tightens his grip on his axe and marches southward.
The fire eats not just flesh, but courage. Even before the blade bites, they burn.
The blade does not burn to destroy. It burns because the rage within it has nowhere else to go.
Enables flaming attacks for Marauder units
The border burns — but this time, it holds.

Forged in a forgotten age from star-metal and quenched in the blood-fires of a ruined southern hold, Brisingr's Oath is no mere axe — it is a beacon of destruction. The blade never cools. It burns not with magical flame, but with something older, more hateful. Its edge is blackened steel, yet red-hot to the touch, and it devours the flesh and souls of those it cleaves.
Win 2 battles against Rogue Pirate factions
Start a turn while fulfilling all 4 boon conditions
Sacrifice all troops and Ascend in to the Avatar of Mermedus
End 35 turns while in Raiding stance
Start a turn while fulfilling all 4 boon conditions
Sacrifice Grydal's troops and ascend as Exalted Daemon of Khorne
Obtain the blessing of Urlfdaemonkin and ascend as Exalted Daemon of Khorne
[[col:red]]Warning: All units and agents in Grydal's army will be sacrificied during the ritual[[/col]]
Finish Gröftur's quests and allow him to ascend perform the Brine-Ascension ritual
[[col:red]]Warning: In case of ascension all embedded forces in Gröftur's army will be lost[[/col]]
Urlfdaemonkin: Finish Grydal's quests and allow him to ascend into Daemonhood
The Brine-Ascension: Finish Gröftur's quests and allow him to receive Mermedus' Gift

Born of blood and black ice, the Snaegr heed no jarl but the Blood God. They feast on flesh, wear bone as prayer, and butcher southward with each Moon-time. Skulls line their path, tongues fuel their fires, and mercy is a word long lost. Their ancestor ascended — now they slaughter to earn his gaze.
The Scourge ascends. The North remembers. And skulls will follow in his wake.
Clad in ruin and crowned in rage, the Scourge has become what his blood always promised — the Exalted Fang of Urlfdaemonkin.

Once, Grydal was merely the most violent of men — Jarl of the Snaegr, butcher of the southern tribes, and wielder of a flame-wreathed axe. But his blood carried a darker inheritance, one older than his name: the cursed ichor of Urlfdaemonkin, the Daemon Prince who first led the Snaegr into Khorne's embrace. Through massacre and moon-rites, skull-thrones and rivers of offering, Grydal won his ancestor’s gaze. Beneath the Moon of Urlf, in a storm of blood and fire, he accepted the final blessing. His flesh tore, then reknit. His axe burned brighter. His roar shattered stone. Now he walks the world as no mere champion, but as Khorne’s incarnate wrath — a being of molten rage and daemonic fury. Horned, clawed, and thrumming with the power of the Blood God, he leads the Snaegr as a living herald of their bloody destiny. Where he treads, the snow melts, the land cracks, and gods look away.

The shame of defeat festers in Grydal’s veins. The Hall of the Snaegr, throne of his ancestors, lies occupied — not by the strong, but by Skaeling carrion. He will take it back, aye... but only as the first step. For Grydal is no mere chieftain. He is heir to Urlfdaemonkin — the first of their line to shed mortality and wear rage as a second skin. Now, Khorne watches. The blood must flow. Skulls must pile. And to the south, legends await — waiting to be broken, drowned in flame, and ground beneath an axe of burning wrath. This is not conquest. This is ascension.

The Hall of the Snaegr burns — its bone-marked gates shattered, its skull-thrones defiled by Skaeling boots. Egil Styrbjorn, pretender and glory-thief, now squats in your ancestral seat, drinking your mead and mocking your name. The gods watch in silence. Urlfdaemonkin watches in judgment. This is no mere insult. This is humiliation writ in ash. And there is only one answer: blood, flame, and vengeance. Take back your hall. Cleanse it in red. Begin the path your forefather carved in gore — the path to Daemonhood.
His word is law. His silence is war.
“The hall lies in enemy hands. The axe is still warm. The south bleeds — and it is not enough.”

Woven from mammoth hide and stitched with the hair of fallen jarls, this tattered war-banner once flew above the Hall of the Snaegr before Skaeling treachery blackened its walls. To march beneath it is to awaken old vows — oaths of violence, vengeance, and honour drowned in blood. The bearer feels the weight of forefathers at their back… and the fire of Grydal’s fury in their veins.
Ability: "Blood of Urlfdaemonkin" after being bestowed Khorne's blessing
His forefather's wrath surges through him — a storm of old fury made new.
Replenishes %n% campaign movement range after razing a settlement for each confederated Norscan tribe
As the blood moon rises, so too do the Snaegr — fiercer, faster, and fanatical.
The Daemon-Sire sees you — and through that gaze, your flesh burns from within.
A vast, mobile altar allows the souls of the slain to be ritualistically condemned directly from the field of slaughter.
A vast, mobile altar allows the souls of the slain to be ritualistically condemned directly from the field of slaughter.
